												My friends always try to get me into Team Fortress 2, but there's a slight problem: they're all mad good and I'm hella stupid at first-person shooters. So when Lead and Gold: Gangs of the Wild West came out, I was excited to switch over to that and be on a more level playing field. It's a fun game (that I don't suck at), but I don't think I'll be able to convince my friends to switch over for more than a couple days.  Lead and Gold is a third-person shooter set in the gold rush era (that's the mid 1800s, kids). You play as one of four different gun-wielding badasses out to get rich and mow down anyone else in their way. The characters are pretty standard in terms of gameplay. There's the pistol-packing cowboy, the sniper rifle hunter chick, the shotgun-miner, and the all around rifle wielding lawman. I love the Old West aesthetic of Lead and Gold. The characters ooze style. The Deputy wears garters and a bowler hat, so I'm pretty much in love with him. And the Trapper is Davy Crockett, reincarnated as a sexy chick. Of course, style doesn't mean the game looks great, because it doesn't. It looks OK, especially for a downloadable title, but it's not pretty. The game looks and feels a lot like Team Fortress 2, with a bit of Counterstrike mixed in. Each character has his or her own special moves as well as these inherent abilities called Synergies. The characters radiate a positive effect to nearby teammates, rewarding teams for sticking together and acting like a team. As players rank up (by earning EXP through killing enemies and whatnot), the Synergies get stronger. The six different game modes mostly focus around getting or defending large sacks of gold. There are Capture the Flag type events, mad dash "grab it all" events, and even more classic deathmatch style modes. All of this takes place in small old west towns, mine shafts, rural farmer homes, etcI like the team dynamic of the game. Teammates can revive you if you get shot down, provided your opponent doesn't come up and blow your face off while you're down (of course you can keep shooting at him too). And the ammo is unlimited, so you never have to stop playing to run around and look for that elusive shotgun ammo spot. As far as which version to get, it's really a tossup. There are more people playing on the PC servers, but that's probably because the game has been out for a while on Steam. I saw no major differences between the PC and console versions.Well, I don&#Array;t think Lead and Gold is going to replace Team Fortress 2 for any of the fans out there. There&#Array;s just not a lot in the game, but what is there is fun, stylish, and cool. If you&#Array;re more of a casual multiplayer gamer like I am, then Lead and Gold is neat game. Just don&#Array;t expect to be playing it for months on end.

												Lead and Gold, is a third person multiplayer shooter taking place in the mid 1800s, in which two teams (red and blue) battle out each other across various gamemodes, or you can play co-op with another buddy and fight off waves of enemies. Note: I haven`t played all the objectives at the time being, due to the lack of players, I may edit this if I ever get a chance to play more objectives.So lets get to it:What I like:- Graphics arent too bad for a 2010 game.- It is fun, especially for a casual gamer.- 4 types of "classes" or characters that have they`re own advantages (we have the blaster, who basically has a shotgun, we have the gunslinger who is also for close range but has a high rate of fire with his pistol, we have the Trapper who is basically a sniper and also has a pistol, and lastly the deputy who has a rifle which can shoot medium-long range.)- Teamplay is promoted, health regen is faster when you are with your teammates, as well as the revive mechanic- Sound isnt that bad, although would prefer if characters said something to give them more presonality.- Movement is crsip and good and responsive.What I dont like:- First and formost, the lack of players is really noteable in this game, which is shocking, given the fact that the developer gave away over 300,000 keys for this game. (there are literally 2-4 servers at a time, thats it)- Gamemodes arent really original (Shootout which is basically team deathmatch, conquest, gold fever which is basically co-op for 2 players, greed where the objective is to get as much as gold sacks to the team`s drop zone, robbery where the attacking team has to destory the bank vault and get 3 gold sacks back to their dropzone, powderkeg where one team defends and the other destroys the objectives with powderkeg).- Lots of lag due to the lack of players.- Also, there is zero motive to keep playing this game, what I mean is that there is no real progression (or leveling up) system in the game nor there is any character customization, and there arent any real stats of you, unless if you go to dig your stats in the leaderboard.- 5v5, I want there to be more players, 5v5 is alittle less, but then again given the small playerbase, it doesnt even matter.- It would also be better if there were more maps and maybe more gamemodes as well.- Boring menu screen.- UPDATE: After playing the other gamemodes, I have to say they all just feel more or less the same.LASTING APPEAL: THIS GAME HAS GOOD VISUALS AND GOOD MOVEMENT AND IS REALLY FUN TO PLAY AS A CASUAL THIRD PERSON SHOOTER WITH THE 4 CLASSES, BUT THIS GAME IS KILLED TO THE FACT THAT THERE IS A LACK OF PLAYERS, LACK OF ANY PROGRESSION SYSTEM AND LACK OF CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION AND IN THE END NOT GIVING THE PLAYER A REAL REASON TO KEEP PLAYING THE GAME. I WILL RECOMMEND THIS GAME, AS I HAVE RECIEVED IT FOR FREE, BUT AT THIS STATE I CANNOT RECOMMEND FOR PURCHASE.8/10 - FREE5/10 - FULL PRICE

Posted: August 16, 2016
												Quite the fun multiplayer shooter, but has some problems with cheaters and there aren't many players. Somewhat recommended.The game features 4 classes with distinctly different capabilities, but it's also well balanced enough that all 4 perform well and get picked fairly evenly. So even though the game's no longer in development, it's still fun to play because nothing is overpowered. Unfortunately, there's the occasional cheater. And even 1 is enough to ruin a game. Usually it's someone who's playing the one class that has an indirect weapon, and throwing that weapon very accurately at people they don't have in their line of sight. Or ambushing them with suspicious frequency. I'd wager there's a working wallhack for the game out there in the cheatosphere.Still, when there are a few players and nobody's cheating, it's one of the most fun shooters I've played.Especially noteworthy are the classes. They're all fun to play. Two of them are a short-range shotgunner and a long-range sniper, whuch have to, respectively, rush in or stay at a distance to be effective. The other two are the short-mid range revolver guy and the mid-long range rifle guy. The reason they all work is that pretty much all the maps are varied enough to allow it. There are usually some open areas that allow sniping, plenty of buildings for short range skirmishes and plenty of cover all around. And the characters move fast and rarely die from a single shot. So firefights are exciting and full of movement and usually last a few seconds.One of the unique things about the game is that when you run out of health, you get knocked to the ground instead of dying immediately. You stay knocked down until an enemy finishes you off, you choose to respawn, or a teammate revives you. And a couple of seconds after being knocked down, you become able to shoot slowly and inaccurately with your sidearm. Still, most of the time you'll just end up getting finished off almost as soon as you're knocked down.When you do die, you can respawn either in the base or on the spawn flag, which any player can pick up from the base and carry around until they get killed. When the flag is dropped, players can still spawn on it, and teammates can pick it up. If an enemy picks it up, it's teleported back to base. This is a cool way to let players jump right into the action.And it also tends to keep most of the team close together, which is great because of 2 other features - synergies and healing. Synergies are bonuses that every class gives to every teammate in range, but they don't stack. So to get full bonuses, you need 1 each of the 4 different classes reasonably close together. And you also get a slow passive healing effect if near teammates.This passive encouragement of team play is great for the game's CTF-style modes. Except it's actually Capture The Gold, and when you're carrying the sack of gold you're super slow, unable to jump, unable to shoot, and can be seen by enemies across the map. So you need your teammates to cover you. The same goes for modes that require carrying a barrel of gunpowder, with the added danger of the barrel exploding after a couple seconds if it gets hit by a bullet.Other game modes are the typical team deathmatch and capture-the-point.Maps are generally good, and some feature oldtimey machineguns in fixed positions, which are fun to use. Although one of the maps has a machinegun in a rather overpowered position near the center.The maps generally prevent enemies from getting into the spawn area, but a lot of the time the fighting will be around one of the spawns, with the attackers throwing dynamite into the spawn. Usually though, the defenders can hold their own, unless there's one of the aforementioned cheaters among the attackers.Gameplay aside, the game has a nice atmosphere. The visuals, character designs, maps, sound effects and music are all consistent with the semi-comical Western feel the game is going for.Finally, at the time of writing, the game is somewhat short on players. It's rarely possible to play outside of evenings in European timezones, and even then there's rarely more than one game going and often none at all, with some players joining if I host. Since this is a multiplayer-only game, a further dwindling of players will make it worthless. But, fears of a multiplayer game running out of players are often a self-fulfilling prophecy, so don't let this stop you. It's a good game, worth your time.

												Not too shabby. Lead and Gold's an addictive multiplayer focused third person shooter that is very immediate, visually impressive, besides being remarkably cheap. I like that the class balancing is spot on for the most part, being fairly flexible moving between play styles aswell, unlike Monday Night Combat in contrast. Lead and Gold's trump card is solid tactical play and teamwork, game modes rotate largely between Attack and Defend playsets which are not to be played in a straightforward manner like in any other multiplayer game. Yet on the downside, Lead and Gold is overshadowed by a poor lobby system and community. Inviting friends into a match, any match, is hard work and there is no clear way of balancing or switching teams without calling for a democratic vote in scrambling teams. Not many players on Lead and Gold will admittedly play fair either, with spawn camping and noob hunting being common sport in matches. Keep this in mind if you consider buying the game.

												A pick up and play game, Lead and Gold has some good points going for it: very skill-based, team-supportive, and a decent variety of maps and graphics. It's a fun game, when it's not utterly chaotic. You can spawn on top of a flag that teammates carry around the map, which is both an interesting mechanic, and very frustrating, when enemies pop up in your face with a shotgun in the middle of you focusing on something else. Explosions, one-hit kills, and anyone able to pop up anywhere (there are no choke points in any map) can make for a very random, hectic, and skill-less battle at times.But if you can put up with it's unforgiving, crazy nature, it's rewarding. Unfortunately there are just a lot of games that do this style way better. The most unique thing it has going for it is the Wild West. 4/10
